Award.AbstractNarration:
With the rapid expansion of computer networks and mobile devices, technologies are in great demand for managing and making best use of large collections of images. Semantic content analysis of images is at the heart of these technologies. The objective of this project is to develop new mathematical tools to tackle crucial and perplexing problems in image understanding. The statistical learning methods and the prototypical system to be developed in this project will have wide applications, valuable for both academia and industry. Software packages will be distributed and maintained for public access. This project will involve undergraduate students in research, and expose graduate students to a broad range of mathematical topics and interdisciplinary topics.

Although advanced statistical learning methods have been exploited to annotate images automatically, existing approaches suffer from both flaws in the mathematical characterization of images and limitations in the modeling of annotation words and image components. In this project, new statistical models will be proposed for images and their semantics. Computationally efficient estimation methods will be developed for these models. Advanced optimization techniques will be used to better characterize images. New large-scale clustering algorithms will be developed for sets of weighted and unordered vectors under the Kantorovich-Wasserstein metric. It is envisioned that the clustering and statistical modeling methods developed in this project will have broader applications than image content analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have developed new statistical and computational tools for machine learning and image analysis and have explored their applications in multiple disciplines. The outcomes of the project include seven published journal or refereed conference papers, software packages for public access, and a US patent. 

The intellectual merits include:

  1. We have developed statistical learning methods for learning from collections of distributions under the Wasserstein metric. Wasserstein metric is attracting growing attention in the past few years due to several intrinsic advantages over other popular distance measures for probability distributions. Distributional data is an important type of data that has much room for the development of fundamental statistical learning tools. As a result, the Wasserstein distance has demonstrated promises in diverse applications such as image annotation, document analysis, and protein sequence analysis. Our new algorithms can play a significant role in facilitating the usage of Wasserstein distance in big data. 
  2. We have also developed new clustering methods by proposing the HMM-VB and deriving computationally efficient estimation and mode calculation algorithms. HMM-VB is an extension of the popular Gaussian mixture model based clustering with the goal of tackling high dimensionality. 
  3. We have also developed new methods based on optimal transport to assess uncertainty of clustering results. In scientific data analysis, clusters identified computationally often substantiate existing hypotheses or motivate new ones. Yet the combinatorial nature of the clustering result, which is a partition rather than a set of parameters or a function, blurs notions of mean, and variance. We overcome that barrier by aligning clusters via optimal transport. We have developed a new algorithm to enhance clustering by any baseline method using bootstrap samples. Cluster alignment also enables us to quantify variation in the clustering result at the levels of both overall partitions and individual clusters. We have developed a R CRAN package called OTclust to provide these functions. Given the widespread use of clustering analysis, these tools are of high potential impact and can increase rigor broadly in the analysis of scientific data.
  4. One important challenge for meteorologists is to effectively integrate simulated forecasting results from multiple numerical weather prediction models or many different forecast realizations by the same model. The collection of these model forecasts is called an ensemble while each forecast realization is called an ensemble member. Extracting overall patterns by direct inspection of a large number of ensemble simulations is prone to subjectivity. In extreme weather conditions, these decisions bear enormous economical and life- saving consequences. However, human cognition is severely limited when supplied with even a moderate number of possibilities. This constitutes a classical example of “information overload” for weather forecasters. It is thus valuable if computer software can automatically summarize the ensemble simulations. We have developed a new paradigm of creating synthesized mean (or average, centroid) images for ensembles of cloud simulations. We call the collection of methods developed here the Geometry- Sensitive Ensemble Mean (GEM) toolkit. 

The broader impacts include: This project has supported three PhD candidates as research assistants. They had the opportunity to work on interdisciplinary research. The project also supported the PI to continue collaboration with other faculty in multiple departments. The research work has also resulted in an approved US patent which includes a technology to automatically crop general-purpose photograph images at high speed and with high quality. Applications of the patent have the potential to impact a broad range of users of mobile devices and computer servers.
